author: Help Net Security
title: Cybercriminals hijack DNS to build stealth attack networks
text:
Help Net Security November 15, 2024 Share Cybercriminals hijack DNS to build stealth attack networks
Hijacking domains using a â€˜Sitting Ducks attackâ€™ remains an underrecognized topic in the cybersecurity community. Few threat researchers are familiar with this attack vector, and knowledge is scarce. However, the prevalence of these attacks and the risk to organizations are significant.
Infoblox researchers estimate that over 1 million registered domains could be vulnerable daily.
More evidence found on Sitting Ducks Attacks During a Sitting Ducks attack, the malicious actor gains control of a domain by taking over its DNS configurations. Cybercriminals have used this vector since 2018 to hijack tens of thousands of domain names. Victim domains include well-known brands, non-profits, and government entities.
Infoblox crafted a monitoring initiative after the initial paper on Sitting Ducks attacks was published in July 2024. The results are very sobering, as 800,000 vulnerable domains were identified, and about 70,000 were later identified as hijacked.
The Vipers and Hawks Feasting on Sitting Ducks Attacks Vacant Viper is one of the earliest known threat actors to exploit the Sitting Ducks attack and has hijacked an estimated 2,500 domains each year since December 2019. This actor uses hijacked domains to augment their malicious traffic distribution system (TDS) called 404TDS to run malicious spam operations, deliver porn, establish remote access trojan ( RAT ) C2s, and drop malware such as DarkGate and AsyncRAT.
Vacant Viper does not hijack domains for a specific brand connection but instead for domain resources with high reputations that security vendors will not block. The newly published report lists examples of attack chains showing redirection techniques used by the 404TDS and their affiliates, including how Vacant Viper uses hijacked domains in the 404TDS.
Vextrio Viper This actor has used hijacked domains as part of their massive TDS infrastructure since early 2020. Vextrio runs the most extensive known cybercriminal affiliate program, routing compromised web traffic to over 65 affiliate partners, some of whom have also stolen domains via â€˜Sitting Ducksâ€™ for their malicious activities.
Many affiliates use a Russian antibot service to filter out bots and security researchers. The functionality of AntiBot includes the ability to set rules to block certain bot services or users based on their IP geolocation, user-agent, etc.
Horrid Hawk and Hasty Hawk The animal designation of Hawks was given because the threat actors swoop in and hijack vulnerable domains, much like hawks dive down to snatch their prey. Infoblox has named several new actors thriving on hijacked domains.
Horrid Hawk: A DNS threat actor that has been hijacking domains and using them for investment fraud schemes since at least February 2023. This actor is interesting because they use hijacked domains in every step of their campaigns, crafting convincing lures containing non-existent government investment programs or summits. They embed the hijacked domains in short-lived Facebook ads targeting users in over 30 languages, spanning multiple continents.
Hasty Hawk: Another threat actor discovered during our research into â€˜Sitting Ducksâ€™ hijackings. Since at least March 2022, Hasty Hawk has hijacked over 200 domains to operate widespread phishing that primarily spoof DHL shipping pages and fake donation sites to support Ukraine.
The actor exploits many providers, often reconfiguring hijacked domains to host content on Russian IPs. Hasty Hawk uses Google ads and other means, such as spam messages, to distribute malicious content. They also use a TDS to route users to different webpages that vary in content and language depending on their geolocation and other user characteristics. Hasty Hawk switches some of their domains back and forth between various campaign themes.
More about attacks cybercrime DNS hijacking Infoblox report Share

author: The Brock News
title: Brock prof among international experts to speak at sustainability panel
text:
Liette Vasseur, Brock University Professor of Biology and UNESCO Chair on Sustainability: From Local to Global, will be a panelist at â€œIdentify and break the barriers to move beyond sustainability to transformative thinking,â€ taking place on Thursday, Feb. 22.
An upcoming public talk featuring a panel of international researchers will discuss the radical thinking and urgent changes needed to preserve life on Earth.
â€œIdentify and break the barriers to move beyond sustainability to transformative thinkingâ€ will take place Thursday, Feb. 22 at 6:30 p.m. in the Newman Room at the Four Points by Sheraton, located at 3530 Schmon Parkway in Thorold.
Brock Professor of Biology Liette Vasseur is hosting the event and will be among the panelists. The UNESCO Chair on Community Sustainability: From Local to Global says experts from a variety of disciplines will share their perspectives on what it means to move beyond sustainability and will present examples of radical transformation that can restore the health of Earth for human survival.
â€œMuch needs to be done, and with the accelerated planetary changes, we urgently need to elevate the discussion,â€ says Vasseur. â€œTransformative thinking and concrete actions are needed to transform our worldâ€™s current unsustainable systems.â€
Panelists include:
- Simone Bignall, Senior Researcher at the University of Technologyâ€™s Jumbunna Research Hub for Indigenous Nations and Collaborative Futures in Sydney, Australia
- Jacqueline Corbett, Professor of Management Information Systems at UniversitÃ© Laval in Laval, Que.
- Mike Jones, an instructor and researcher at the Uppsala University and the Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Centre for Biological Diversity in Uppsala, Sweden
- Christie Manning, Professor of Environmental Studies at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn.
- Liette Vasseur, UNESCO Chair on Community Sustainability and Professor of Biology at Brock University
There will be time for the public to comment and ask questions of the experts to further the discussion.
The event is part of a larger project,
Beyond Sustainability: Radical Transformation Through System Thinking, co-led by Vasseur and Professor of Philosophy Christine Daigle, Director of Brockâ€™s Posthumanism Research Institute. Supported by a New Frontiers in Research Fund (NFRF) â€“ Exploration grant, which is funded by the Government of Canada, the project brings together experts in environmental science, philosophy, economics, Indigenous culture, performing arts, literature and political science to work with local and international community groups on creating a more sustainable social-ecological system.
While in town, Vasseur and the other panelists will be participating in a NFRF-supported international â€œthink tankâ€ at the Brock LINC Research Impact Hub from Wednesday, Feb. 21 to Friday, Feb. 23 to continue the conversation and plan for further action.
Registration is not required to attend â€œIdentify and break the barriers to move beyond sustainability to transformative thinking.â€ For more information, please email Brock NFRF Research Assistant Jocelyn Baker at

Cooke down to a paste consistency. Set aside Cut sausage in half lenth wise and cook in the sauce pan till done. Cook egg to preferred doneness Toast the bread, when toasted , add cooked sausage on top, and then the bean mix and then the cooked egg and mushroom on top

author: @TheGlobalHerald
title: Skunk water sprayed at worshippers near Al-Aqsa Mosque - The Global Herald
text: Al Jazeera English published this video item, entitled â€œSkunk water sprayed at worshippers near Al-Aqsa Mosqueâ€ â€“ below is their description. There has been a skunk water truck which has been spraying water towards Palestinians and Muslim worshippers. This produces an awful smell, which has been drifting in the air. People have also been attacked with tear gas grenades. The reason why there are these confrontations is that, since October 7, there have been vast restrictions on Muslims entering the place they revere as the third holiest place in Islam, the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound. The Israelis are only allowing people over 45 years old, but even then, they can restrict them. We have only seen about 3,00 to 4,000 worshippers in the past two weeks. Usually, youâ€™d have between 50,000 and 60,000 people praying in the mosque. So thereâ€™s been real tension here.Al Jazeera English YouTube Channel Got a comment? Leave your thoughts in the comments section, below. Please note comments are moderated before publication.

author: VOV
title: Ho Chi Minh City cancels May 1 drone light show
text:
Ho Chi Minh City cancels May 1 drone light show Thursday, 10:57, 01/05/2025 VOV.VN - Ho Chi Minh Cityâ€™s Department of Culture and Sports has announced that the planned drone light show featuring 10,500 unmanned aerial vehicles (drones) on the evening of May 1 will be canceled.
A rehearsal of 10,500-drone light show over Saigon River on April 28 On April 30, the city had attempted to launch the show, but it was suspended due to signal interference. â€œTo ensure flight safety, the organizing unit decided to halt the performance and retrieve the drones,â€ the department added.
Earlier, on April 28, the city held a rehearsal of the light show featuring 10,500 drones.
The event received enthusiastic support from a large number of residents and visitors. This was the largest drone light show ever held in Ho Chi Minh City.
HCM City to celebrate national reunification with record-breaking drone show Ho Chi Minh City is set to celebrate the 50th anniversary of southern liberation and national reunification on April 30 with a spectacular lineup of events, headlined by a world-record attempt featuring 10,500 drones in a stunning light show.
VOV

author: Anujj Trehaan
title: Go for these forest hikes in Bavaria
text: Bavaria, Germany, is a treasure trove of natural beauty, especially during fall when the forests turn into a vibrant palette of colors. The crisp air and the rustling leaves underfoot create an enchanting atmosphere for hikers. This guide highlights five must-visit forest trails that promise breathtaking views and a serene hiking experience in the heart of Bavaria's autumnal landscape. Tegernsee is more than just a lake; it's an autumnal wonderland surrounded by forests that blaze with color during the fall. The Neureuth trail offers panoramic views of the lake against a backdrop of golden larches and fiery maples. This moderate hike is about six kilometers long, making it perfect for a day trip filled with stunning vistas and peaceful moments in nature. Nestled on the border with Austria, Berchtesgaden National Park is renowned for its breathtaking alpine scenery and untouched woodlands. The Wimbachklamm gorge hike invites you on a journey through enchanting forests ablaze with autumn colors, alongside the soothing sounds of rushing streams and cascading waterfalls. This trail, ranging from easy to moderate difficulty, truly encapsulates the essence of Bavarian wilderness in the fall season. Just outside Nuremberg, the Lorenzer Reichswald is a dense forest rich in history and natural beauty. In fall, this area transforms into a vibrant mosaic of colors, making it perfect for leisurely hikes or bike rides along its well-marked paths. It's especially appealing for those eager to combine outdoor activities with a touch of historical exploration, offering a unique experience amidst the changing seasons. Near the famous Neuschwanstein Castle, Fussen offers hikers the Lechfall trailâ€”a path that winds through vibrant forests alongside the Lech River. In autumn, this trail becomes even more magical as the foliage turns brilliant shades of orange and red. It's an easy hike suitable for all ages, offering enchanting views that seem straight out of a storybook. For those seeking adventure at higher altitudes, Garmisch-Partenkirchen offers the Partnachklamm gorge hike. This trail, encircled by cliffs adorned in autumn's palette, blends natural beauty with a physical challenge. Hikers can experience the beauty of cascading waterfalls weaving through forests of golden trees. This unforgettable journey showcases some of Bavaria's most spectacular landscapes, ideal for immersing oneself in the tranquility of nature's autumnal change.

author: newsdirectory3
title: Delhi Air Quality Plunges to â€˜Severe-Plusâ€™ Category
text:
Delhiâ£ Gasps for Air as Pollution Reaches â€˜Severe-Plusâ€™ â€Levels for Fourth Straight â€Day Delhiâ€™s air quality plummeted to alarming levels â¢on Thursday,marking theâ£ fourth consecutive day the city has been shrouded in a thick blanket of smog. The overall Air Quality Index (AQI) plunged into the â€˜severe-plusâ€™ category, raising serious health concerns for residents. â€‹While a slight improvement to the â€˜severeâ€™ â€Œcategory is â¢predicted for Friday, the situation remains dire.

â€‹ â€Œ â€ŒPeopleâ€Œ wearing face masks amid thick smog in Delhi on Thursday.

The â€˜severe-plusâ€™ category, with an AQI reading between 451â€ and 500, â€‹poses significant health risks, particularly for vulnerable populations like children, the elderly, and those with respiratory conditions.Delhiâ€™s 24-hourâ£ average AQI reached a staggering 451 on Thursday.The alarming situation has sparked criticism from â£the opposition Bharatiya Janata Partyâ¢ (BJP). virendra Sachdeva, president of the â£BJPâ€™s Delhi unit, accused the ruling Aam Aadmi Party (AAP)â¢ government of inaction.
â€œPeople have been suffering â€Œfrom pollution for an extended period,and for the last 72 hours,the city remains under Stage-IV of the â€ŒGraded Response Action Plan,â€ Sachdeva said.â€This leaves all residents troubledâ€Œ in one way or another. â¤Neither Chief Minister Atishi â€Œnor Surroundings Minister Gopal Raiâ£ has addressed the gravityâ€Œ of the â€Œsituation.â€
The cityâ€™s air quality is expected to remain a major concern in the coming days, highlighting the urgent need for effective â£measures to â¤combat pollution and protect â¢public health.
